div.head: In connection with Amitāyus-Amitābha and Sukhāvatī
div.p: Dundubhisvararāja, rnga sgra’i rgyal po, seems to be an epithet of Amitāyus or Aparimitāyus tshe dpag med as the name initially Amṛtadundubhisvararāja is used to introduce the dhāraṇi in the Aparimitāyurñānahṛdayadhāraṇī Toh 676/850 and also occurs within that dhāraṇi.

The text is clearly about tshe dpag med in the sense of Amitāyus-Amitābha, since it involves descriptions of the western buddhafield of Sukhāvatī, despite its title, which could lead one to believe it was about Aparimitāyurjñāna also tshe dpag med but tshe dang yeshe dpag tu med pa in long form.
This text is also cited in Tibetan literature and Indian?? as rnga sgra’i rgyal po’i gzungs and it may perhaps be as a result that the epithet is applied to Amitāyus-Amitābha.
In the Tibetan tradition, this appears to be the most common use of the name rnga sgra’i rgyal po Dundubhisvararāja.
div.head: As a buddha of the northern direction
div.p: In this same ? connection the Japanese and Chinese? traditions seem to give Dundubhisvara as an alternative name of the buddha of the Karma family associated with the north, i.e. instead of Amoghasiddhi. See https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amoghasiddhi
There may be the variant Dundubhisvaranirghoṣa as a buddha of the north see Edgerton.
